I was not a fan of the hot and sour soup. It was overall, too spicy for my taste. S enjoyed it though! The sesame chicken and walnut prawns were both great. 

To be clear, this is takeout Chinese food, and I have to say it is reliably tasty, not as greasy as most places, and also has good delivery services.

After the first dine-in experience, we have been mainly getting takeout from them, and they are quick everytime! Online ordering also makes things very easy.
author: Alison C.

description: $50 for dinner for 2. Sushi was a little better than what I would get at 7-11 or Trader Joes. When we told them about the free California roll with orders over $25 they charged us for one roll and "gave" us a second for free. They forgot our crab rangoons then accused us of lying about receiving them. My wife took a few bites of her chicken skewers, vegetable dumplings, the tempura was cold and soggy. When I told the delivery that came back because of the forgotten rangoons my wife was not happy with any of her food he shrugged his shoulders and said then don't order from us. Then at the end of our conversation he used profanity. NEVER GO HERE!!!
author: Scott K.

description: This review is not about the food but about the delivery service. The driver arrived to our building and called us to come down to pickup the food because he did not want to come up to our apartment. We asked him to come up to our door  and explained to him how to use the call box. He called back 5 minutes later and yelled at my husband that he has waiting downstairs for 5 minutes for us to come get the food and said he would not bring us the food. We had to call the restaurant and talk to the manager in order to get him to deliver our food.
author: Melissa F.

description: So far the best Chinese food you can order through EAT24 or at least that I have ordered thus far. Love this place!!
author: Marin H.

description: The seaweed and salad and lychee dessert brought to me were super warm. The salad was completely inedible, warm, had no flavor and tasted old.
author: Tamar G.

description: I don't like liars. I don't appreciate getting a call saying my food is at my door and then standing there for 4 minutes waiting for him to actually arrive. That's lying, screw you, I'm not ordering from you again. City Chopsticks is far better.
author: andrew f.

description: Food was good but the waitress was surly. Empty restaurant but she acted put out that she had to bring us anything. I guess next time i'll get take out.
author: Brenda F.

description: Homey walnut prawns is the best in town.. veggie freaking fresh!!!!! Delivery usually within 40 mind which is faster then average restaurant. I would definitely recommend people to come try it out.
author: Hailey A.

description:
when we walked in on a late night (around 11pm), there were two guys complaining to the waiter about how little meat in the peking duck dish was. I could see where they were coming from, but those two guys were being total jerks to the poor waiter who was trying to be nice and explain the situation. Anyhow, it wasn't a nice way to start our experience there.

the food was okay. their chow mein is ridiculously salty and their house soup is just bizarre. overall it was a very salty experience.

their general chicken was the only dish we liked out of everything we ordered. I might try this place for it opens until late and offer delivery but won't visit again.
author: Sung C.

description: THE WORST.  over 2 hours late......and still not here.  their phone number goes straight to a full voicemail box.  go to mcdonalds, that is better for your mental health.
author: Nico S.

description: In terms of a balance between quality and price, Bamboo is one of the best values for SF Chinese food. Service is also strong. Most Chinese restaurants conveniently "forget" to include chopsticks, napkins, or extra hot sauce (when requested). Bamboo always delivers on  utensils and condiments.
author: Marc C.

description:
This was the most disappointing Chinese food experience I have ever had.  I am not a negative yelp reviewer but with this low of quality people should be warned.  My roommates and I decided to order some of the most basic items that cannot be messed up by even the most elementary Chinese restaurant.  To start the cream cheese wontons that we ordered were horrific.  The texture of the wonton itself was not crispy nor soft, just a leathery texture that left me with cuts and disdain in my mouth that I still can't shake.  A wonton is supposed to be crispy, simple as that.  Then instead of cream cheese, it was a minuscule piece of minced meat, it was unidentifiable and resembled what I would assume rat tastes like.  Then move to the fried rice.  I mean fried rice is a staple of many Asian meals and one of the easiest things to prepare, but somehow Bamboo messed it up.  The rice felt like I was putting spoonfuls of sand in to my mouth.  After I added a healthy amount of soy sauce I was able to choke down the "fried rice soy sauce soup".  Possibly od-ed in salt after this meal just so I could taste something pleasant.  We did not even receive our chow mein that we ordered which was probably a blessing in disguise because of the low caliber of the rest of the meal.  The sesame chicken was soaked in sauce and hard to chew so I assume that this was also labeled chicken but really some type of rodent.  I could keep going but you get the point.  

Actually my favorite part of it all was the fact that the delivery guy had the nerve to call my roommate and demand her to walk out to his car.  Talk about service, its 2013 bud, get off your ass and do your job.  Delivery means to our doorstep.  

Run Run Run away from Bamboo as fast as possible.
author: Patrice K.

description:
Off on an adventure, searching for Chinese food in the Nob Hill/Polk Street area, I'd heard good things about Bamboo. A friend had said several times that we'd check it out and I finally dragged a friend to it when looking for dinner Friday night. Despite it being 8 pm or so on a Friday, it wasn't busy at all. We were able to grab a seat quickly and get our food delivered toot sweet.

Pros: extremely affordable prices ($24 for two of us and we both ordered a cup of hot and sour soup plus an entree each), extremely fast service, friendly and courteous wait staff (our waters were refilled often), complimentary tea, and fake meat options for the vegetarians (this is one of the things that *really* makes me happy with Chinese food restaurants, and it isn't as common to get as one would think!)

Cons: the interior of the restaurant is pretty small, tables are almost side by side. Makes it a wee bit difficult for conversations that you don't want to share with the general public other than your dinner companions. Also, the menu seems to be a little bit mislabeled. I ordered the General Meatless Chicken and there were no chili pepper markers on it (which indicate spicy). My first bite had me coughing from the overwhelming vinegar and spiciness of it. It wasn't over-the-top spicy that I couldn't eat it, but it definitely wasn't mild in the least. As it hadn't been marked, I was a bit unprepared for the heat. 

I would happily go back here and think I might make this my general goto place for delivery from now on as it's just right around the corner. While the hot and sour soup isn't the best I've had, it's pretty damn good in general, and with the fake meat dishes, I'd be more than happy to try it again.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Have been here many times. Nice quality chinese food, friendly staff too. Lunch specials are the best, right portion and right size for one.
author: Hems B.

description:
Bamboo was a nice place to grab some food. Pretty much your standard Chinese food. The orange chicken was really good with a nice crisp to it. The mushu was also really good but the asparagus chicken was kinda fishy.

This place is solid but not exceptional. If your in the area and craving Chinese food, stop on by.
author: Ryan J.

description:
I ordered beef teriyaki, dumplings, and wonton soup for pick up.

Beef teriyaki: there was a good amount of flavor but the meet was a little tough and dry. 

Dumplings: not to much dough and inside cooked well. However, the outside was dry. 

Wonton soup: perfect but not super warm. But the broth wasn't too salty and the wontons were not too doughy. 

My meal would be considered average but for the price paid I cannot complain. The meal was decent but nothing stood out making it worth going back.
author: Stewart C.

description:
I stopped in here for a rice plate because my favorite spot - Sam's - was closed for vacation.  The food was awful and I will never eat here again.

Ordered black beans & chicken over rice.  Got a plate of chicken, squash, carrots and bell peppers (nothing really Chinese about that) covered in a dark and thick soy based sauce with no evidence of black beans in it.  The sauce in this dish is typically light because the black beans provide the flavor.  The rice also seemed to have been reheated because it was hard.  The meal included a fried egg roll and a wedge of orange plus a bowl of soup.  The egg roll and orange were ok but there was nothing Chinese about the soup -- it was  basically chicken broth w/a few veggies in it -- broccoli and cabbage.

The meal was cheap ($5.65) but had nothing else going for it.  There are lots of other restaurant options on Polk St and I'm surprised that this restaurant has survived.  If you want Chinese food, go to Sam's a few blocks north (when it's open again) or go to one of the many other restaurants located only a few steps away.
author: Martin C.

description: OMG the food is amazing The soup was amazing the food was fresh and warm it was just really good I would  definitely come back again
author: Yaya C.

description: The crab rangoons are amazing. Quick delivery, fairly priced, and the fact that they serve both Chinese and Japanese food is great - no need to compromise with the boyfriend.
author: Ashley C.

description: Potstickers odd taste of tea-not edible. Rushed, cheap Hunan tofu, decent tasting chow mein, decent veg curry with vegetables not overcooked which is always a nice surprise. This was unfortunately a very stereotypical ethnic meal and would not stand a chance among Chinese people or anywhere except where our standard is ridiculously low in the category.
author: emily m.

description: We ordered Lemon Chicken. I'd expect chicken breast and a light batter with lemon sauce. Instead we got ALL dark meat with fat and gristle, heavy batter and a very sweet syrup. It was really like sweet and sour pork. It is a saucy soupy goo. I've had much better in the area. The people were very nice but this item was what I'd find in an all-you-can-eat buffet.
author: Chris L.

description: This place is just okay.  The food is not awful and it's not amazing.  Call me old fashioned, but I feel like when you pay almost $11 for orange chicken that there should be an expectation that it will come with a small portion of white rice.  Not the case.....that's extra.  Your $11 gets you a box of chicken, that's it.  Not a soul in there when I walked in at 7 PM on a Tuesday night.  Maybe there would be if they included the rice....just saying.
author: Brian W.

description:
CPMC is not that far from Bamboo. I like that you only need to spend mimum $10 when you order for delivery. (and, you don't even to pay cash, they can take your credit card too)

Our swing shift crew ordered 2 dishes of Beef with Oyster sauce, a large hot and sour soup, Hunan fish and rice. Yes, you are charged extra for it. Hence the total: $38.65

Delivery was quick and our food was piping hot. 

The only thing I wished that they had more was seafood choices. Fairly decent selection of prawn dishes, but I need more fish entrees. (Golden Horse has better choices for seafood)
author: Janice C.

description:
I haven't really tried anything other than the Spicy Chicken dish (in a plum sauce).  I believe the kids would call it "amaze balls" but I would call it the "bee's knees."  (Disclaimer:  While the knees of bees may actually be an ingredient, it matters not.)

Oh!  It's also cheap and they deliver.  And you can order online.  These are all good things.  Okay, good talk.
author: Kaare W.

description:
This is another one that I would give a 0 star. Gross, gross and did I mentionGROSS! I even tried it again just in case I was off. I threw the rest of what I could not tolerate away. I live next to this place so how bummed am I that it SUCKS! :0(   

Do not be fooled by the pictures.
author: L W.

description:
Great service - delivery is always on time and the employees are very easy to work with. This place is my go-to restaurant for catered employee dinners where I work. The food is good and the price is definitely reasonable. Every time I've called, the employees were always helpful and the delivery is on time (if not sometimes 5-10 minutes early), every single time.

The only reason I'm reserving a 5-star rating is because they are not super on top of their serving sizes. Last time I called to ask about ordering trays for 30 to 35 people and the person on the phone recommended the medium-sized trays. When the food arrived, I took one look at it and realized that there wasn't going to be enough food. Low and behold, there wasn't enough and I ended up ordering 4 more large pizzas from a place down the street for everyone.
author: Gloria Z.

description: The food here is ok, but the best part about this place is how much food you get for such a low prices. Its a very sizable portion. The place feels very family oriented too. They were playing cartoons on the tv. Pretty cute. In general there was nothing too memorable, but if I ever end up here again, I'd feel just fine about it.
author: Dexter H.

description:
First time visit here, just ordered the sauteed Garlic Eggplant with steamed rice to go.  Holy sugar rush Batman!  The sauteed Eggplant was incredibly S-W-E-E-T, so sweet. Yikes!  Thank goodness for the steamed rice to help choke down the sweet food.  What the heck?

Also, when I arrived, I watched the same Chinese lady from the reviews complaining very loudly to another customer about the tip that was left on another table.  I quickly changed my order to take out.  She is not nice or happy.  Bless her heart.  I was one of only two people in the place, and she was still impatient.  Like Seinfeld's "Soup Nazi" episode.

While I waited, I watched these two big turtles trapped in too tiny an aquarium on the shelf, just sit there waiting to die.  So sad.  I wish I could have been able to set them free.
author: KIMO J.

description: We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to bamboo. The service was friendly and efficient and we were promptly greeted with a pot of hot tea. Our meals were bought out promptly after ordering. The chefs special combination is amazing. All food is cheap. If I was a local, I would definitely be spending a lot of my time and money getting food from this place. Thank you so much :)
author: Tegan S.

description: I haven't reviewed in a while but I felt compelled after ordering Bamboo from Seamless (and I'm not being productive). They were on time, if not earlier, with delivery. They have options I haven't seen in most chinese delivery menus, like asparagus and salt fish fried rice.  These two items and the chicken with black bean sauce were solid, flavorful, and what seemed like a large serving size. Definitely ordering from them again.
author: Ingrid K.

description:
Hunan cuisine is very flavorful.
All meals come in such large portions and are so tasty!

Lunch plates are the size of dinner entrees so come with an appetite.
Their specials are pretty much all $5.95 except for a few.

Spicy Chicken with Basil is a hit.

Service is pretty quick, especially during lunch hour when people come to dine from work who are on a time limit like me.
author: Elisha Y.

description: Great traditional Chinese food. Price is great and large portions. The lunch special is a steal!
author: Stacey R.

description:
Tasteless, greasy food and the worst customer service I've had in a long, long time: 

Ordered delivery at 5pm on a Sunday (so there is no way they were busy) and it took them over an hour to deliver. When the food finally arrived we open the boxes to find that it was the wrong order.  When my friend called the restaurant they acted as though we were lying, HUNG UP ON HER, then when she called back they made her list every item that we ordered + every item that was delivered to us while they decided if they wanted to fix our order or not... After over 20 minutes and ANOTHER HANGUP they finally agreed to make the food that we originally ordered and redeliver it (would have cancelled the order but we used Seamless and it's a huge hassle to get your money back, plus at this point we were starving and desperate). It then took them about an hour and a half to deliver it... I understand that mistakes happen, orders get mixed up NBD, but this was so, so not ok.
author: Katelyn P.

description: This place is one of my favorite places to eat at. Its some good quality food. My girlfriend and I go here a lot and just love it. The food is so tasty! I recommend everyone to eat the honey walnut shrimp here and don't skip out on the sushi. Not only is the sushi pretty, it tastes amazing!
author: Thomas T.

description:
super fast delivery...i think they were at my house 15 minutes after i ordered.

pretty tasty too.

and they have brown rice...me likey!
author: Ripley B.

description:
What do i do when I want some decent Chinese delivered to the girl's apartment? I turn to Yelp, of course. My fellow Yelpers had good things to say about Bamboo, and I trusted you. Ahh, the wisdom of crowds ... Trouble is, this time you messed up, crowd. When has a mob ever gotten something wrong? Surely this is a first.

The food wasn't all that bad, and the delivery time was very good. I'll give them that. But the hot and sour soup was like 3/4 vinegar, which was not good.

Girly didn't like her kung pao chicken so much, and my crispy noodles were a little lackluster. Maybe this was an off day? Preparing for the new year celebrations and not paying that much mind to the kitchen? I dunno, but Bamboo dropped the ball on this one.
author: Wes T.

description: Eating here for the second time, the waitress was rushing myself as well as my date to decide our orders. I felt as though I was under pressure to make a fast decision quickly when making my order. There was only one waitress serving two customers. Waitress seemed in a rush throughout our meal. The food is good but the service I would say needs more humility, respect, as well as better engagement with and of customers. Lunch special is a good deal.
author: Ayelet H.

description:
Skip it. The fried rice was dreadful, the beef tasted cheap and the chicken was fatty.  The wings were pretty flavorless.

The crab rangoo was amazing with the sweet and sour sauce and the chow mein is good if you don't order it with meat.  This place is probably a lot better if you are a vegetarian because the meat isn't worth eating.
author: Jordan F.

description:
Ordered Hunan fish with Fried Rice. 

Like: They offer lunch deal until 5pm. They don't close during mid-afternoon. Waiter service is good. Nice interior. Really like the chinese teapot to self-serve tea. The fish is very fresh and soft. Good price!

Dislike: Got a vege soup that is OK, quite salty. I asked for more spicy, it turned out just nice for me, but it was VERY salty. I drank lots of tea. The fried rice wasn't really well-cooked, the rice was probably yesterday's rice from the fridge, which is acceptable but have to be cooked thoroughly.  Despite the saltiness, I still ate all of the fish.

50-50 chance to go back.
author: Jane A.

description:
Someday when I'm close to death and my life flashes before my eyes, I will think long and fondly of Bamboo's Sesame Beef, and all the incredible love it and my taste buds have made together.  Even when it's  overcooked, it's an instant train ride to flavor country.  

Unfortunately though, the overcooking happens too regularly, and most of the other dishes are too forgetable for this to be more than an occasional stop for me, even though I live just up the block.  

Only a semi-requited love, even though I would've given it all up for you, Sesame Beef.
author: Harrison A.

description: I like the lunch special. I order the orange chicken and white rice. The female waitress is really rude though. I order takeout and she throws the bag on the table. She doesn't hand it to me or make eye contact. Would love someone working here with people skills.
author: Misael F.

description: The guy who delivered the food was such a dick I lost my appetite.
author: Patrick A.

description: Just awful.  Fast delivery, but food does not taste good, period.  I tried to fight through it, but ended up just throwing it out, and eating a few handfuls of popcorn instead (was much more satisfying).  Will never order from here again.
author: Eric H.

description: I've had a lot of bad Chinese food over the years, so I know what I'm talking about. This place was just bland. My beef and prawns tasted like 5 spice gravy and little else. The pineapple fried rice was tastless and un interesting. I've had better from the freezer section at Safeway.
author: Lando H.

description:
They're ok.  Decent enough Chinese food.  Good prices on their lunch specials.  Delivers for free for others over $15 or $20 (can't remember).

Appetizers are pretty good.  Restaurant itself is pretty comfy and red fabric draped over the ceiling.

Can't tell you much about their bathroom.  I assume one exists, but I'm afraid to find out what it looks like.  I just sometimes get that way, not their fault really, or any indication of what the rest of the restaurant is like.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Got the appetizer combo, honey walnut prawns, asparagus and salmon with black bean sauce, and brown rice.

Wow. After looking at some other reviews I guess we ordered the right things? The main courses were great and the portions were large. The walnut prawns, as others have said were excellent. The sauce was not full of mayo as I've seen at other restaurants. Asparagus with salmon and black bean sauce was great as well. The veggies were not overcooked and the salmon was perfectly done as well.

Why not a higher rating? The appetizer combo . . . the appetizer combo had 2 each of pot-stickers, egg-rolls, crab rangoon, and chicken drumsticks. Pot-stickers were good with the wrapper not too thick and doughy. Crab Rangoon was likewise very tasty. The chicken drumsticks were pretty bland and the egg-rolls were just something to occupy time with.

That said, they also have brown rice and don't charge your for tea like other Chinese restaurants in the city. Bonus points!

Solid 3.5 stars. 

I'm rounding it up because of the entertainment value. I heard one of the employees answering the phone "No! We are not salon. We are Chinese restaurant!!" well, I thought it was funny!! ;-)
author: Andrew C.

description:
I'm sick. I've caught the flu and did not get out of bed until 2pm today. The feeling that I feel right now is like death warmed up. I'm hungry. What do I crave? Gross Chinese food. Greasy, oily Chinese. Where do I go? Yelp. Yelp always has the answers. I wanted somewhere close to minimize the length of time it would take to get my food. Bamboo had decent results. 

Called at 5pm, got my food at 5:45pm. Not bad. Pretty fast. The delivery guy was really nice. I gave him a $100 bill and unfortunately, he only had $80. So I scrounged for change to give him as a tip, and ended up with $3. He was pretty cool about it. I did warn the place when I called in that I only had a bill and could pay by CC. They said it would be okay. But alas, I was embarassed to not have any other smaller bills on my to give him. 

Food was pretty decent. I got the salted fish fried rice, which was pretty good although they skimped on the salted fish. The hot and sour soup was "okay". It had a funny taste to it. Definitely not what it should taste like. $20 for an entree, fried rice, and hot and sour soup. Not bad at all.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Very friendly service, huge portions, yummy food, great prices, and long hours. What's not to like? It was one of the first restaurants I ever went to when I visited the city, long before I moved here. I love that you walk in, sit down, and immediately get soup, salad (at dinner) and tea. 

The times I've visited it's been pretty empty inside. It's mostly a delivery place. But I like the walk and eating there. 

The mango beef is fabulous.
author: Amber D.

description: fake japanese food. i ordered the chicken karaage and it straight up tasted like costco chicken nuggets.
author: Leslie M.

description:
HORRIBLE!!!  I will never order from this place again. 
First, they did not honor the "free spring roll" with purchase over $20 because I ordered online, not over the phone.  
Secondly, the food arrived way too fast, which makes you wonder how fresh the food was.
Third, the food was awful, the Won Ton Soup tasted like ditry water and the beef dish was definitely mystery meat because it did not taste like beef.
Overall, we ended up throwing the food away because it was just that bad.
author: Mariana A.

description: Hey if you want normal plain chinese food, give this place a try. Its def a no frills type of place. But the food is comforting because it's not very outlandish. Works in a pinch when you're starving, but please don't go out of your way to go here.
author: Rich_kids_of_yelp Z.

description: I ordered the dinner special for sushi. The rice was dry and tasted like minute rice. The seaweed salad was soggy and watery. Took almost 2 hours for delivery. Definitely not ordering from here again.
author: Emily M.

description: Best General's Chicken I've ever had. My family ordered a second serving halfway through our meal. We will go back just for this dish.
author: Denise T.

description:
Second time ordering food from Bamboo and just have to say: SO FAST! This past time I ordered via Foodler and they were at my door near Alamo Square in about 30 minutes, I think less than that.  I had fantasies of going on the elliptical machine before the food arrived to balance the inevitable gorging, but that didn't happen.

Anyway, the food is hot and good. Vegetarian pot stickers and Kung Pao Tofu are good bets.
author: Austin S.

description:
I am always weary of what type of meat may be disguised as Chinese food, but at this place, it tastes so good, I don't even worry about that! 

I have had both delivery and eat in service. Both were quick, large portions, and tasty! I have had orange chicken, general cho's chicken, and hunan beef. They were all delicious, had tons of sauce (which I love so I can mix it with my rice), and had good spice to them. I honestly couldn't tell the difference between the 2 chickens, but at least they were good! 

The restaurant itself is actually really cute. It is on Polk street right across from the Polk street gym. The restaurant has plants, nice fabric on the ceiling, and a great background music that actually sounds authentic. As soon as you sit, they bring you a teapot. There was only one other table when I was there because we were there between 4 and 5 which is obviously a very odd time. However, it was good for us because we still got there in time for the lunch special. For less than 6 dollars you get a meat choice, rice, and egg roll or for less than 8 dollars you get 2 meat choices, rice, and egg roll. 

The one complaint I have on this place is the egg roll. Neither me or the guest I went with liked the egg roll. It is hard to say why it wasn't good, but I think if the veggies inside were chopped up more rather than being nearly whole, it may have been better. 

This place definitely satisfies my delivery need and my "walk 6 blocks for good Chinese food" need.
author: M M.

description: Great prices. Food quality is good. Quantity is above average. Service is jus ok. Probably recommend take out for those who like chinese.
author: Greg B.

description: I had great service, small quiet atmosphere.  The Kung Pao (the did Scsllops for me even though not on lunch menu) was outstanding!
author: Kate B.

description:
I'm so sad. I normally do a ton of reading/research on yelp before going to a doctor or eating from a restaurant. What's horrible is that I spent about 20 minutes reading 2 pages of lengthy reviews for Bamboo and even though 1/2 were horrible 1 star reviews, I took a chance anyway since there were a few 4 star reviews and I wanted to try something different. I had hopes that I would agree with those few people who actually liked it. It was late and I was ordering online--I was feeling spontaneous! :(

I used to LOVE Yum Yum House which closed down---and I hear Big Lantern is the same owner but I don't think it's as good. Jasmine Tea House is ok too but I was curious to try a new 'General Tso Meatless Chicken" since veggie Chinese chicken is always good (or so I thought) and I actually figured most places used the same stuff (I think a lot of places use Leona's). I mean, how can you go wrong with deep fried soy protein balls covered in a sweet and spicy sauce? YUCK! 

I read another review which said they felt bad throwing away the food they just spent money on. I ordered:

General Tso Meatless Chicken
Vegetable Chow Mein
White Rice

The veggie chicken looked amazing, but I took one bite and immediately spit it out. It had an awful rubbery-bouncy texture (not like other soy chickens I've had that shreds more) that I could barely chew and bland sauce. There were ZERO vegetables (lots of places serve this with at least a good serving of crisp green broccoli) and I couldn't even eat ONE piece...and I NEVER throw food out...I love food and am not picky. I enjoy delicious fresh organic food but will enjoy an occasional crappy piece of frozen pizza or chinese food any day.

I added the veggie chow mein even though it'd be too much food, because I needed to meet the $15 minimum for delivery (i love eat24hours.com) and figured that would be hard to screw up. The chow mein was so bland that even when I re-sauteed it with garlic , onion and shoyu it was still bleh. I liked that it had a lot of bright crisp veggies though, I'll give them that.

Someone said they screwed up the white rice. My rice was actually perfect. It was soft and steaming when I opened it. Too bad I didn't have anything to eat it with :( I was excited to eat the fortune cookie but noticed it had hydrogenated cottonseed oil which I couldn't bring myself to eat (if hydrogenated oil wasn't bad enough--cottonseed is the most toxic!) 

I just wasted $20. I should've just ordered from Big Lantern and saved on the gas emissions from him coming from Polk st (I'm in the Mission). 

Oh, and when the delivery guy came, he told me I owed him money even though I paid online with my credit card 30 minutes ago. He tried to check his phone and finally believed me when I told him I paid through eat24hours.com.
author: katherine m.

description:
Abstract:  Fresh ingredients all the time!

Review:  My food was just delivered and it was quick!  The advertised time is 45 minutes and they got here in just over 20.  Granted, I do live in Nob Hill, 0.5 miles away.

The vegetable egg rolls aren't the most flavorful I've had, but they are definitely made with fresh vegetables--there was an unmistakable cabbage crunch in every bite.
The egg flower with sweet corn soup was also kind of bland, but that's what it's always like, right?  It's filled with sweet corn, carrots and peas that are also quite fresh and surprisingly really crunchy.
Sesame chicken is one of my favorites and it's listed under Chef's Recommendations, so I had to try it out here and I am not disappointed.  The chicken isn't overwhelmingly battered--those tiny pieces scattered around aren't bits of batter, they are actually chicken!  It has a rich flavor and delightfully light crunch.

Ordering online was a breeze, but I had to switch browsers because zonic ordering isn't well-supported on Google Chrome.  Having the option to pay with credit card is so convenient, however, I don't know whether the tip option goes to the delivery-person or not.

Fresh ingredients, affordable prices and quick delivery will keep me coming back to Bamboo.
author: Vinney L.

description: Not very friendly service, food was bland. Flavour is not authentic! Overall not a very pleasant experience. Wouldn't recommend to anyone.
author: Laura C.

description: This has to be the best lunch special in the city. The vegetarian Kung Pao is delicious and service is quick if you are pressed for time. A quirky thing is the music selection, which is usually Mexican Mariachi. Not super high end, but a great regular location.
author: Chris L.

description:
Warning: very bad delivery service!!

I ordered food there and tip them 10% of the bill. The delivery guy rudely told me I have to tip more, otherwise I am not allowed to order from now on. I called the place and they hung up on me. I've had bad experiences with Chinese restaurants before but this is by far, the worst customer service I've ever seen.

P.S. The food doesn't taste good, either. Just go somewhere else!
author: Ken N.

description: I have tried the beef, broccoli, prawns and we were pretty satisfied, five minutes, and a satisfied belly!
author: Lorrs L.

description:
Let's start this review with a story.

My friend, whom we will call "Norman" for the duration of the review (name changed to protect the ..critic), is extremely picky and often not willing to try new places.  "Norman" is also the one who bitched and moaned about going to Loving Cup because it wasn't his beloved tried-and-true Tuttimelon, and then ended up falling in lurrve with Loving Cup and went there four days in a row after his first time.

"Norman" is kind of a night owl, and when we hang out to have dinner, it's usually past 9 or 10 PM.  Yesterday, I was the one who had to work late, so I picked him up around 10:15 and faced the dilemma of finding a place nearby (Polk St.) to eat.  "Norman" was dismayed to find that Tai Chi, one of his favorite shrimp war wonton soup joints, was closed already, and as we headed up Polk, he found out that the Vietnamese place a few blocks up was also closed.  Since I'd snagged a spot in front of Bamboo, I quickly Yelped it on my iPhone and saw that it had 3 stars.

A quick peek inside showed zero people eating, but the "OPEN" sign was still lit.  When "Norman" looked inside and pointed to the door, the waitstaff motioned for us to come on in, and after deliberating for a few seconds ("There's no one inside!" "Well maybe because it's 10:30 already and the majority of the Bay Area is done eating dinner?"), we walked in and were seated.

It's a tiny restaurant that's relatively clean.  No hours are posted, but I think they close at 11 PM.  It doesn't seem very "Chinese" because the menu only had items written in English.  Weird, right?

So we sat and ordered: green onion pancakes with peanut sauce (what?? peanut sauce?), and "Norman" had the bamboo war wonton soup, and I just had the regular wonton soup.  They have either a small or large size, and I asked how many wontons were in the small bowl.  The waiter said 4, so I told him that I wanted the large bowl.

The green onion pancakes were kind of really crispy, not quite what I'm used to at other Chinese restaurants.  There was an unsweetened peanut sauce spread on top (think old-fashioned, salted peanut butter, not the Jif kind), and I have to admit, it tasted kind of good with the peanut sauce.  I tried licking all the peanut sauce off and then tasting the pancake, but the peanut sauce definitely gave it a different kind of taste and texture that I preferred.

The wonton soup actually really sucked.  Majorly.  On a scale of 1 to 10, "Norman" and I decided that it was either at a 3 or 4.  It had a tiny fingernail-sized lump of pork with ginger, and it was completely enveloped in a thicker wonton skin.  The broth was mostly flavorless, but had some sweetness to it.  Not even soy sauce and gratuituous amounts of salt could save my soup, so I sucked it up and ate my wontons, making a mental note to never come back.

After dinner, "Norman," who knows I Yelp a lot, told me that I needed to review it stat. So, kudos for accepting credit cards, staying open late and being clean.  After we started eating a few more couples came in and ate well past their open sign turning off, and no one rushed them or acted pissed off that they were staying past closing.

$18ish before tip.  $22 total for a completely unsatisfying meal.  I wonder how the rest of their food tastes, since apparently Wilhelm Y. liked their Mongolian Beef.  Maybe I'll stop by sometime when it's lunchtime, so the prices are cheaper.
author: Tori S.

description:
I learned alot about euphemisms by dining at Bamboo.  For example, when ordering the onion cake with peanut sauce, I learned that "peanut sauce" is a euphemism for "Jiffy peanut butter" and "onion cake" is a euphemism for something that doesn't taste anything like an onion cake.  If you're unlucky enough to order the "red china prawns", you'll learn that "red china" is a euphemism for "ketchup."  Yep, they put ketchup in the sauce.

Beyond the euphemisms, you'll find the occasionally palatable dish:.  hot sour soup is fine, as is the hong kong crispy noodles.  Points for being cozy inside.  Hmm... that's about as good as I can do.
author: Laurence W.

description: Delivery was not so good. The chicken lost all the crisp and was soggy. I would definitely go back for eat-in, but look elsewhere for delivery.
author: Bern H.

description:
I ordered take out from here the other night. The crab rangoon and wonton soup was delicious! 

However the sweet and sour chicken barely had any chicken, the shrimp we ordered tasted "off" and we didnt eat it. Also I expected some rice to be included and there was none, so I think its definitely overpriced for what we received. 

I'm going to keep this in my back pocket but continue to look elsewhere for my SF chinese food.
author: Nihad P.

description:
The bf and I have only ordered for delivery so I have no idea what the restaurant looks like or how their service is. However, I can say that delivery has never taken more than 30 min and the food arrives pipping hot!  :)

Their egg foo yong is da bomb!!! Seriously. The taste is just perfect! The amount of veggies is stupendous!
He likes the duck and pork fried rice. I like everything veggie I have tried there. Their fried shrimp is decent, tho last time I found a hair in mine :(
author: joanna r.

description:
I've had dinner in the restaurant multiple times, and also had food delivered (ordered via http://eat24hours.com).  I have never had a bad meal: they will make the food very spicy, the soy protein meat substitute is really good in the General's "Chicken," they have brown rice, and will make off-menu items for you for the same price as a comparable on-menu item.

The crabby poofs (crab rangoon) are filled with tons of filling, the sweet and sour sauce is both sweet and sour.  The hot and sour soup is nice and peppery as well as both hot and sour!  Their various vegetable dishes are always full of flavor, taste fresh, and arrive via delivery hot!

Brown rice is not totally mushy when you order it, which is good, because it means that they are making it multiple times a day.

The restaurant is clean, the service is good, and they are just down the street from Bob's Donuts, so you can get a buttermilk bar to take home!
author: Paul B.

description:
Well, I had a complaint about the change in decor and staff but the new pictures they put up on their wall did actually help me find a new favorite dish, the Hong Kong crispy noodle, it's amazing, even the next day when it's no longer crispy. 

So now I have two favorites I have to get every time - the General Cho's chicken and Hong Kong crispy noodle dishes.
author: Cristina S.

description:
I really have nothing bad to say about this place. I always get the lunch special (which goes until 5 and only costs on average $5.50 or something). It comes with the main dish, rice, and an egg roll. Sold. And they have crab rangoon, which for some reason is a rarity around here, and it tastes just like the crab I used to get before I moved out here. On top of all that they have a low delivery minimum (only 10 bucks) and they're open until midnight every day. Delivery usually seems to take about 25-30 mins.

I've never been into the restaurant so I can't judge anything on that but Bamboo is everything I need in a Chinese place...cheap, delivers, fast, and delicious :)
author: Jasmine J.

description: Tasty, reliable, and made with love. Bamboo never disappoints and has plenty of options for the vegetarian in the family. Their noodles dishes are great and not at all over oily. I always get their Kung Lao tofu and Singapore noodles and finish both. Highly recommended,.
author: Nathan T.

description: We ordered in for lunch through Grub Hub. The Mongolian Beef was SO bland - no spice, no salt, no flavor at all. Straight to the garbage. Maybe I just picked the wrong thing?
author: Candy C.

description:
Excellent service, polite waiters, and really good chinese food! My dad can be a pretty hard man to please...for some reason as he gets older, he's becoming a bit more skeptical about, well, everything.  He was happy. Enough said.

We came here for a family lunch and were not disappointed. The waiter was soooo nice, which is why the incident that unfolded shortly after we ordered pissed me off. This fat guy comes in and orders. He doesn't like the dish that he ordered and kept stating that he knew what REAL chinese food was and that this was just horrible, he had to send it back, and blah, blah, blah...

Long story short, sir: This has nothing to do with the food, and if you want it cooked a certain way, and you KNOW how to cook chinese food, cook it yourself. Idiot. 

I felt so bad for the poor waiter. Our food was perfect and he was so accomodating. Kudos to him for keeping his cool because I was about to tell that guy to get the fuck out and I didn't even work there!
author: Seanté B.

description: Good food, quick delivery. Wanton Soup was strange, odd color and didn't taste like any other wonton soup I've had.
author: Stevie S.

description: Gosh this food was good!  For six bucks you get more than enough food.  Vegetarian specials are everywhere but the beef was melt in the mouth good.  I was impressed that the soup didn't taste like dish water and the rice was fluffy and lively.
author: Veda F.

description:
the food was hot upon delivery


I ordered off GrubHub using my smartphone app.  It was decent.  Nothing to write home about, but I didn't get sick.
They did not give me a fortune cookie, that made me kind of sad.  Probably wouldn't go back unless it was the only thing open and I was really drunk, as was the scenario last night.
author: Light Bulb J.

description: Bamboo was delivered to our office for lunch and it was filling and good. They arrived within the 45 minutes we were quoted and for lunch they were only $6.95 per person! What a deal. The sweet and sour chicken was good, but I tried the Kung Pao and really enjoyed it. The peanuts were really good. Overall, a cheap lunch but not incredibly exciting.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I experienced this place on the day i had to do street cleaning, when i got this random stupid parking ticket, and I am too cheap to pay for it.
I ended along the streets of jones and leavenworth, picking up garbage. It was raining, and cold. I was sick, I just wanted a hot noddle soup.
There was nothing on the menu, and I was served, the most nastiest... bowl of food. ugh.. I swear will never come to this place ever again!
author: Monika T.

description:
Delivery was fast, order-taker over the phone was quick and accurate.

Only read this review if you have any intention of ordering their wonton soup or wor wonton soup.  Otherwise, skip this review as it adds no value to your life.

I take back my ode to Wor Wonton soup which, thanks to yelp's policy of allowing only the rating for my most recent review count towards the business' average rating, makes me feel undeservedly self-important, like managers everywhere during their employees' evaluation time.

I only wish I could take back my order earlier this week for not 1 but 2 Wor Wonton soups, just like I wish I could go back in time and take back my health and my youth.

I may not be able to help you with your health or youth issues but I can save you from the bad in Wor Wonton soup, specifically the Wontons.

It's been a while since I've ordered from them as my fave dish is their Wor Wonton soup, which I order only if it's rainy and cold.  I would even order it for lunch delivery in the Financial District during wet weather and everyone at work would regret not ordering with me when I asked them if they were in or not.

Here's what is still delicious about the Wor Wonton soup:
1. can replace beef with decent quality chicken
2. contains juicy shrimp, although in smaller quantities
3. has baby bok choy
3. same amazing ginger with green onion broth.

HALLOWEEN COMES EARLY
Here's what has changed for the worse:
A. Replaced wontons filled with pork and chives/green onions with some kind of mystery meat that tastes gross.

MYSTERY MEAT - WHOSE MURDER IS IT?
I don't eat mystery meat if I can tell it's mystery meat.  Ground meat at a restaurant is considered mystery meat in my eyes.  I don't like meat scrapings.  No hot dogs from the non-licensed vendor on the corner of Mission and whatever for me.  No hand rolls using scraped fish pieces because who knows what type of fish I'm really getting.  And definitely no packaged ground meat from the local grocery store.  I'd rather eat vegetarian food.  Now, I'm not saying that there's not some savvy food entrepreneur who hasn't sold me a false bill of goods, telling me that I'm eating a certain animal or animal part when it's (fill in unappetizing flesh here).  But I go out of my way to avoid mystery meat and do whatever I can to know what I'm eating, ever since some fly-over-state coworkers thought they'd try to pull one over me by having me try Rocky Mountain Oysters which have NOTHING to do with Oysters - luckily the waiter took pity on me and warned me off the Rocky Mountain Oysters.

The reason why I say that the wontons are filled with mystery meat is because it's ground meat, ground so fine it's impossible to tell what it was unless you send it for analysis at a lab.  And it doesn't taste like the pork that I'm used to eating at Chinese restaurants, but maybe that's because I DON'T ORDER GROUND PORK at Chinese restaurants.

MYSTERY MEAT HELPS CONTROL PORTION SIZE IN TIME FOR HOLIDAY DIETING
I was greedy and I had ordered two Wor Wonton Soups for two separate meals.  It was so bad that both soups turned into 4 meals even after I had picked out all the wontons out of the soup since they just grossed me out so much.

TURNING JAPANESE
It will be a while before I go out to try a wor wonton soup anywhere.  for now, I think I will stick to the chicken and veggie and egg udon soup at one local japanese restaurant or the veggie soba soup at another as that's what I've been using to cleanse my palate for the last two days since you know what.
author: Geeta S.

description:
If I ever see wait staff clean there ears out before serving food (thank god it wasnt mine) I will yelkl at them.

ITS DISGUSTING.

A point for a clean table.
author: Razza M.

description:
Love that they deliver in under 30 minutes!!  
We were staying at a friend's place in the Tender Nob area and were not able to leave the building (long story-don't ask-lol) and found this place on YELP and decided to order delivery.
We ordered Veggie Egg Rolls, Green Beans in Plum Sauce, Egg Flower Soup, Veggie Soup, Tofu w/Eggplant, brown rice and sodas and love love loved all of it! 
Food was piping hot upon arrival and the total price of all that food was very reasonable.  There was prob food left for the next couple of days.
Thank you Bamboo  for feeding a couple of starving girls from out of town!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Wow, delivery was super fast; less than 30 minutes!  Presentation (yes, we are talking delivery) was excellent!  I had the Mu Shu Chicken, Spicey Eggplant (which wasn't very spicey) and Pork Dumplings = $19 including tip.  Portions are huge, prices are low, so the above ='s about 3 yummy meals for me!  The only thing that was disappointing were the Pork Dumplings only because I thought they would be like the kind you get for dim sum.  Although not what I was expecting, (these were more like unfried Won Tons) I was surprised by the presentation (they were draped in seaweed and placed on a bed of lettuce for gosh sakes!), and the flavor was deliciious!

Food: 3 1/2
Speed of delivery: 4
Bang for your buck: 3
Overall rating 3 1/2
author: Lauren H.

description: This review is solely with respect to orders out, and with respect to vegetarian food. This place is ridiculous. Some of the time when I order food, it's moderately on time, but often it takes more than twice the time they list/provide for delivery. On top of that, the last two times I've ordered the "vegetarian" chicken version of something, it has come with real chicken (verified by people who actually eat chicken). Oh, and on top of that, they don't pick up their phone so you can address any issues in person.
author: Aditi I.

description:
The main thing going for this place is that they deliver to my flat.  I don't remember when I ordered the food, so I have no idea how late they're open.  I guess I could look at the website, but that's way too much trouble for me right now.

I'm always kind of conflicted when it comes to Chinese food.  I like it.  But I'd rather have Thai food.  And a lot of the vegetables are common to both kinds of food, at least in the US, so eating Chinese food is kind of like eating cantaloupe; I'd rather have Thai and watermelon, respectively.

I will say that they have a good selection of vegetable dishes--who ever knows whether cheap places really respect the vegetarianness of their customers?--and the delivery was relatively quick.

I'd like to say I'll give this place another go, but with so many Thai places I haven't tried yet, why should I?
author: John S.

description:
WOW. The Shanghai Chicken is a force to be reckoned with.

Just tried this spot out last night for delivery and this is probably one dish I will be ordering from them every single time. It is chopped chicken, sauteed in a mild spicy sauce with pine nuts and crispy seaweed flakes. Everything is perfect and the crispy seaweed flakes really make it fantastic.

Delivery was fast and cheap also...you can order online at grubhub.com. SO EASY!
author: Cindy P.

description: Whaaa? I'm confused. Bell peppers, mushrooms, and some leafy green vegetable in my chow fun? And how did the color get on those noodles when they taste like nothing at all? Granted, it was cheap. $7 for some takeout. But still, I had to walk up a hill to get back home and throw it away. Not cool.
author: Elisabeth G.

description: Try the dumplings.  They were excellent.  We had the spicy scallops too.  They were also very good.  If I lived nearby, I would be a regular.
author: Melissa L.

description:
'Twas the night before Christmas and my staff was bored and wondering why they were stuck at work instead of home with their families. I need help like culinary motivation and something for us to share over a holiday. Given my inability to cook or create something that doesn't taste like paper from my desk, I did what any logical person would do - I ordered Chinese! 

Recommended to me by a concierge, I called Bamboo. The food was pretty good and the service was too. The gentleman taking my order was friendly and the delivery driver was also very nice. We ordered fired rice, brown rice, Mongolian Beef, Sweet & Sour Shrimp, Sesame Chicken & Crab Ragoon all for under $40 after delivery, tax & tip. I was impressed that it was so affordable and actually really good food. I would certainly call them again!
author: Marissa P.

description:
I don't know, man. I just don't know. To start, they give you this small plate of lettuce with ranch dressing on it, and then a sweetish soup which seems to consist of cabbage in sugared broth. How these appetizers fit into the category of Chinese food is one question, and how anybody decided that they would be a good thing to precede any meal is still another. Further elements contributing to my mystification include the decor, which consisted largely of big idealized photographs of dishes ringing the dining room's entire perimeter, as if to say, "In case you forgot, this is in fact a restaurant, really!"

Service was courteous and fast but my order was totally misunderstood and had to be redone. Unfortunately I had wanted to come in, eat, and get out sans lingering. When I did eventually get the food, it left me wondering if I got my eight-dollars' worth.

God, I feel lousy dismantling this place, but I have to advise looking elsewhere when you're wandering aimlessly down Polk looking for a quick bite of Chinese.
author: Peter B.

description:
It was another rainy day in SF, and none of my coworkers wanted to brave the dash to get lunch. We consulted our delivery menus and decided on Bamboo. What a great idea! 

I love my Hot and Sour soup hot, both in temperature and spiciness. What other restaurant delivers Hot and Sour soup, and the soup is hot enough (temperature-wise) to burn your tongue? Nice spicy kick and sour tang, too. 

I enjoyed the soup AND the free egg roll that came with it.
author: Patty W.

description: Bamboo restaurant in San Francisco. The decor was very nice, authentic feeling for a Chinese restaurant. The service was excellent. I liked the fact that they give you a soup and salad straight off the bat without even asking. It was very light and refreshing. It was also helpful that they had the pictures of the different meals on the wall. They also served hot tea without asking which was nice too. I had the Shanghai Chicken that was basically finely chopped up chicken with pine nuts and dried parsley. My husband had Moo Shoo chicken which came with paper thin tortillas. It was very tasty. So overall good food, good service. Horrible parking especially if you want to go for dinner.
author: Tricia K.

description:
Bamboo has some yays and nays.

Yay--I requested certain sauces on the side and different chicken (I'm a health freak) and they easily accomodated my requests.
-fast service
-friendly waiters

Nay- food is a little too Americanized
-I ordered the brocolli and chicken with almonds and it didn't have that soy sauce taste that most Chinese dishes do. Maybe it's because they "say' they don't use MSG so it was lacking a bit of flavor?
--the free soup they give tastes like a clear minestrone with cabbage. It doesn't taste very asian infused.

Overall, the prices at Bamboo are cheap and reasonable but if you're looking for a real Chinese restaurant, this isn't the place to go!
author: Joy A.

description:
The food had a strange consistency and no flavor. I tried to eat it, despite the fact that they brought me the wrong thing. Speaking of which, here's what the managment at Bamboo told me about the mistake they made with my order:

"Our vegetarian meals have some meat in them..."

Yeah, that was their excuse for arriving late, with the wrong order, consisting of soggy, bland and tastless gruel. They refused to replace anything, which is bad enough. But worse off, I'm pretty sure that this was the best they could do, even if the order was correct.

Seriously, don't go here, no matter how convenient it is to get it from Delivery.com.
author: Kay H.

description:
Yuk. If I wanted my egg flower soup to have corn, carrots and peas in it I would have ordered egg flower soup succotash style. Bleck! And how can you call your crispy duck that when it's cushioned in an inch and a half of greasy fat? The two stars are for the delivery guy, who was nice and located my hard-to-find flat without drama. 

Otherwise, Bam - BOOOOOOOO!
author: wendella a.

description:
Food-wise, I really enjoy their sesame chicken; it's really the only thing I get here.

I'm prompted to write my review now because I was very concerned with the hasty delivery guy.

Now, I'm not complaining about their speed to get the food out to me.  I'm complaining about how short he stayed there to wait for me to get down from my 2nd floor apartment (with NO elevator).  I just had to throw on my shoes and run down 2 flights.  He rang twice and within less than a minute (really, I'd say not even 45 secs), he was GONE and going back to his car!

I couldn't believe it.  Being fast is a plus, but too fast in the wrong places is a minus!  If he didn't see me at the gate, I bet he would've sped away.

That was my first time ordering delivery; and I think from now on I will always keep doing take-out; when I'm starving holed up for the night at home, I don't want to risk losing my dinner in just 20 secs!
author: Kitty O.

description:
I was in the mood for some Chinese food and had no desire to leave the house...after a quick yelp search I decided to give Bamboo a shot.  Food was decent- good chicken w/ green beans, bland won ton soup, passable shrimp noodle roll.  The one saving grace was the delivery time-I had my food in under 15 minutes.
Oh, and the fortune cookie was top notch although the fortune was kind of a buzzkill:  You shouldn't overspend at the moment.
WTF?
author: phil h.

description:
I've ordered delivery from these guys at least three times.  They actually nail almost every order as I would expect the dish to taste.  

The only thing that lacks a bit of luster is the duck dishes and the hong kong style noodles.  It was a little soaked rather than topped with the sauce.  As always, chinese food is always greasy, and the food isn't necessarily special but decent.

The driver is always nice, and will call way ahead of time if he can't find your pad, you know, rather than drive around aimlessly for 20 minutes before calling you and telling you they're lost.
author: Alfred Y.

description:
Forgettable, that's what you are

In-edible, though near or far

Like a cockroach crawling in my delivery

How the thought of you does nasty things to me

Never before has Chinese been more

Forgettable, in every way

And forevermore, (And forevermore)

That's how you'll stay, (That's how you'll stay)

That's why bamboo, its regrettable

That someplace so forgettable

Could be inedible ... poo.
author: Brad C.

description:
This place was delicious.

We stopped in after randomly walking up Polk Street. They have pictures on the wall of all their dishes. They brought us some sort of cabbage with dressing (I didn't really eat this - hubby said I woudn't like it and I trust his opinion) and also hot tea (which was great). I ordered the chicken with pinenuts and steamed green leaves (not sure what kind of leaves they were - maybe fried spinach?). My food was amazing. I don't really care for Chinese food - usually because it is overfried and tasteless, but this was great. I would go back in a heartbeat. Or at least order take-out from this place.
author: Nancy B.

description:
SAN FRANCISCO, CA- In one of the most shocking and horrifying events to ever strike the city, a sudden outbreak of what scientists are now calling "MSG Rage" is sweeping through San Francisco at a ravaging pace. The infection is believed to have started at a local Chinese restaurant named Bamboo off of Polk and California. Witnesses state that the first "Infected", as they are now being called, burst through the door of the restaurant and immediately began attacking men, women, and children, anybody in possession of water, juice, or a sports drink. Scientists state that MSG Rage causes "extreme swelling of the brain, numbness of extremities, and a vicious, unquenchable thirst."

A local man, Sam Kingsworth, was the only person at the restaurant to have escaped infection. "It was horrible" he sputtered out, in between tears and gasping breaths. "We had come here for lunch, you know me and some coworkers. I had just taken a bite of the fried rice, and it was horrible, just absolutely horrible. It tasted like Pez, you know those little candies, like some one crushed em up. Fried rice isn't supposed to taste like Pez! Oh God!"

His hands shook as he recalled the terrible events that were about to unfold. "And then Jimmy" he continued "and then Jimmy started eating his sweet and sour pork, and all of a sudden he starts twitching and shaking and slobbering out his mouth. And then he grabs my glass of water and drinks it, drinks the whole damn thing. And I say "Jimmy you son of a bitch", cuz you know we would call each other sons of bitches and what not, and I say "That's my goddamn water Jimmy" and he throws the glass across the room and looks me in the eye and hisses "Whhhhaaaahhhhtttteer! Waater" And I'm lookin him in the eyes and I know that Jimmy ain't there no more."

Kingsworth states that soon after, his other two coworkers started exhibiting the same symptoms. "Then Mike and Larry are shaking and screaming, and they start fighting each other over the last glass of water. Larry smashes the glass over Mike's head, and kills him, and there's no more water. Then Larry starts looking at me and I know what he's thinking, because Larry's always talking about this survival course he took a few years back in Michigan, and how they said if you are ever dying of dehydration to eat the eyeballs of whatever you kill, because it's got a lot of electrolytes. "I'd do it, you bet your ass I would!" he would always say. And I yell "You ain't eating my eyeballs you crazy son of a bitch!" and stab him in the neck with my chopstick."

Reports cite that a man, later identified as Jim Wellswal, ran out of the restaurant with hands full of sweet and sour pork, stuffing it down the mouths of whomever he could catch, infecting them. Authorities advise  everyone to stay inside and lock there doors until the situation is under control, and by no means answer the door if someone says "Delivery!"
author: Dave G.

description:
i've ordered to-go from Bamboo about a dozen times.

i recommend the Mandarin Eggplant in plum sauce, it comes with chicken AND prawns! big portion too :)

if you order over $20, you get free egg roll or the soup of the day, but you have to order for delivery or pickup.

it's one of my go to places in the city. the guy's that work there are super nice and polite, they get an extra star.
author: Bruce A.

description:
Eating at this restaurant is a good way to cause hemorrhaging in your intestines. If you're in the mood for comfort food you need to walk further down Polk and eat curry at Shalimar, where you will still end up on the can for the night, but at least you will have enjoyed getting there. 

This place is called bamboo because that's how hard your excrement is going to be in two weeks when your digestive system finally allows you to evacuate the now two week old chinese food from your body.
author: Richard S.

description:
The crab rangoon tasted like it's been sitting under a heat lamp all day. There wasn't too much crunch on it and tasted stale. 

The hunan beef was okay but nothing spectacular.
author: Helen V.

description:
Mia K. and I were intending to go to Wayo Sushi last night, but the Junichiro Koizumi lookalike chef (according to nobu) was no where to be seen so we headed towards Polk and came upon this little restaurant.

Mia had the Shanghai Chicken and I had the Red China Prawns.  Both dishes were listed as spicy, and they were acceptably so without being overwhelming.  I see that some of the reviews are mixed, but my experience here was good.

On a Monday most of the business seemed to be delivery or take out, so it was a quiet restaurant.
author: Beau G.

description: I've had this place twice. The food is very light in that it isn't drenched in oil and sauce. The food and quality are pretty good, and the prices are very reasonable. Definitely a decent place to go out for a casual bite to eat or take out / delivery.
author: Neal F.

description:
If you looking for reasonable price and good Chinese food, you are in the right place.

We had Honey walnut prawns, Sesame chicken and Hot & Sour soup last night, These dishes were great. 

The service was nice as well. Also it's easy to find parking on the street.
author: Sasitorn O.

description: Never wrote a review before, but this place really takes the cake, in a very bad way. Service (the hostess was extremely rude, she shoved the tip I gave her in the jar with total disgust) and food was extremely poor. Awards posted was misleading to me. If you want quality food and service, go elsewhere. Be forewarned!
author: Beverly V.

description: I come here for the crab rangoon or rather the whole combination platter of fried goodness. Now my friends and my BF enjoys a lot of the meals like the  mu shu or salt and pepper pork chop however the one thing this place seems to be lacking is a healthy vegetable meal. Which is up my alley -- now I'm not a vegetarian but every once in a while when I eat here with friends I'd love something simple. But even the Spinach with Tofu & Mushroom soup feels unhealthy. Now I know that usually people going here aren't looking for that kind of option so if you're going with standard meals from here then sure, it's decent.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Almost every time when I get really bad flu/cold and have high fever and can not move from my small apartment, I order bamboo. I crave for bamboo's onion cake. It's so fattening. Deep fried Chinese tortilla's and peanut butter sauce (cooked onion's are in the layers of deep fried tortillas). It's SOOOO GOOD! When I am so sick (really) and need energy and cheering up, that's good enough excuse for me to eat the fattest thing usually I avoid, you know?

Then last time I ordered the dumpling for the first time. That was amazing, too. That will be the new items on my list. Because the dumpling skin wasn't too thick like some other Chinese restaurant. I hate thick skin dumplings...

I used to order them for my lunch from my office all the time, I ate lot's of their spicy sauce eggplant (because I can not live without eggplant and mushroom). They are pretty good also.

Viva! Bamboo onion cake!
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
Huge portions of bland food.

Prices are good at 6.50 for a two item combo with rice, soup, and egg roll. So yea. You'll get full. That's about it. 

The egg roll was hands down the worst I've ever had. Not because it tasted bad but because it had no taste at all. 

The interior was the best part. It's very small and dark. The vibe is almost like eating in a tree house. A tree house with a nice view of Polk street, which makes for good conversation. 

They do have the option of brown rice which is always nice.
author: Chelsea T.

description:
I had the day from hell yesterday, so I decided to take myself out to dinner. While walking around the neighborhood I stumbled upon Bamboo, and the nice relaxed vibe, dim lights, and cute decor drew me in. 

They weren't busy and I was seated immediately in a cute little table right in the window and given a complimentary salad thing, which was alright, and a pot of tea. At this point I am most pleased and beginning to forget about my totally fucked up day.

I started with a bowl of the egg flower soup, which was very good. For dinner I got the fried tofu with eggplant in a spicy garlic plum sauce type stuff. This was what made the whole experience worthwhile, it was sooooo delicious!!! The tofu was perfectly fried; it was the best I've ever had. The eggplant was soft and tasty, and there were red bell pepper chunks too. The sauce was what made it though, it was just spicy enough to have a kick with some sweetness added by the plum.  I could probably drink a cup of that sauce. Then to finish my dinner I had some green tea ice cream, which was good too. Nothing to write home about, but its green tea ice cream, its pretty much the same everywhere you go. 

My bill came to just under $14, which I think was pretty good, considering that the portions were huge and the service was awesome. I most definitely couldn't have finished everything. The service was good too. I'll definitely be coming back here.
author: Slasha S.

description:
This is the best Chinese food joint I have found yet in the city and my wife and I ate here for under $20!  (17)  It's because the portions are huge we split a sweet and sour chicken and a chicken fried rice (especially great).  My wife was crazy about the chicken flavoured tofu soup served as a complimentary appetizer.

The atmosphere of the place is great - especially at night.  Nothing over the top, but very cozy feeling with the lighting they have used.  The servers were very courteous too.  One couple stormed out in an argument of some kind after paying for their meal and the server still made a point of thanking them for coming!
author: Jesse D.

description:
I came here for dinner with a ravenous appetite to destroy all gastronomical creations after a long ass day.  Also I was going to this lame ass bar in the marina afterwards and wanted to brew a few nasty stank-bombs for my own entertainment at the bar afterwards.

We got the green onion pancakes, chicken with basil and crisp duck.  Your food comes with a cole slaw like salad (which I didn't eat because I hate mayo), vegetable soup (which was rather bland) and steamed rice.  The duck was presented very well; small pancakes and green onions came with the dish which the waitress put together for us one by one.  The chicken was OK - spicey but kind of bland;  not comparable to any Henry's.  The green onion pancakes were bland as hell in all aspects - the cake itself had no taste, the peanut sauce on top only had a weak peanut taste.
The people here were awesome, very friendly and caring.  They ensure you're comfortable, you have enough tea and stop by for conversation and laughs.  Unfortunately the food wasn't par with the service here and thus 3 stars.

Afterwards, I had a brisk walk to the marina which successfully helped brew a nasty case of the stank bombs that I unleashed upon the people at the bar.
author: Nico M.

description:
The mu shu is a Fing joke. It's as if they chopped up half a cabbage head, doused it in some warm hoisin sauce and voilà, your mu shu is served. Disgusting. The egg drop soup tastes more like creamed corn and has a gelatinous consistency (which I'm usually partial to but not in this instance.)

I basically order from here on Sundays when King Ling (The Best) is closed. One star bc they have brown rice. I've ordered shrimp from here and it came with the shit still in it which I'm surprised I didn't have to pay extra for. Don't request chopsticks and soy sauce upon delivery or you will get none.
author: Seymour G.

description: It's satisfying food.... but not authentic Sichuan or Mandarin.  They put way too much sugar in spicy dishes as a way to appease the lesser taste buds.  But hello, Sichuan cuisine isn't supposed to be sweet!  That'd be like making Cajun food sweet and sour.  NOT right.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I've ordered through delivery as well as had takeout from this Chinese food joint on Polk.  And I've had very good service either way.  The food is your standard Chinese fare, but they've always been accomodating with my takeout order (e.g., fried wonton sans meat), and extremely hospitable during my wait, including serving me tea while I sat and waited!  

Have a meal here mid-day when you can take advantage of their lunch specials.

Edit 9/4/06: They offer veggie chicken here.  You might want to double check it isn't real chicken before biting into it, though.  When I ordered this, something made me stop more than halfway through my meal to check and see what kinda chicken it was.  I still don't know if what I ate was real or not. =(
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I am not a big fan of Chinese food... however, sometimes I crave it... in these times, Bamboo is where I choose to order from.

Good food, good prices... EXCELLENT orange chicken.  Really fast delivery.  Wonton soup which doesn't involve peas or oddly colored broth... winners, I say they are!

(For some reason I felt compelled to write that last part as Yoda.  Don't know why - not enough coffee have had I... hm?)
author: Kate R.

description:
There is something about Chinese delivery that is just freaking killer.  You get the little buckets of food, a smelly apartment and usually every place has some freebie that you get when ordering enough items... I always order enough items.

The food is pretty darn tasty although after playing slosh-ball all afternoon with 50 or so of my closest friends I think I might have also been impressed with the taste of a sweat sock.  The leftovers are telling the true story of the mediocrity here.  I will say that the potstickers here are truly the B-O-M-B and I will never turn down food here... I will be thankful for the fact that I will only be ordering from bamboo when I am wasted or lazy... when my palate is more 'accepting' of so-so food.
author: Thadd L.

description: Good food, huge portions, and it's ridiculously cheap. Not much else to say.
author: Gabe F.

description:
Lightening fast delivery. How they can make the food and deliver it in less than 20 minutes is beyond me. The food is quite tasty. Great sesame chicken and pot stickers. 

Bamboo would have gotten 4 stars had it not been for its extremely low rating (41 out of 100) on the SF Dept of Health website (something about immediate risk of cockroaches). But it's so tasty and quick that its worth at least 3 stars.

FYI, the dept of health rating for Bamboo is available at: http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=298
author: Dave S.

description:
I got delivery from Bamboo on a Sunday night because my usual "Chinese" take-out destination (King Ling) was closed. It was pretty much a disaster. My food showed up an hour and a half after I ordered, and was largely inedible. The potstickers were full of gristle and disconcertingly rarer than pork should ever be. The sesame chicken was over-seasoned in what I will assume was an attempt to disguise the crappy chicken inside. And the white rice. Oh man. I know that most people think white rice is unimportant, an empty starch to pad a meal. But I happen to be a big fan of steamed white rice. Most "Chinese" restaurants provide passable sticky rice with their meals, and that works for me. But the rice from Bamboo tasted like it might have been cooked two or three days ago and microwaved before it was sent to me. The grains were slightly hard, and it was no longer sticky. You can't build a meal with that kind of foundation. Eugh.

If you find yourself looking for "Chinese" food some time, I recommend looking elsewhere.
author: James B.

description:
Hot and Sour Soup was strange and disappointing, and the Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings needed more spice, along with chopped garlic, jalapenos, and green onions.

Mango Prawns, Beef Chow Fun, and Duck Fried Rice were all pretty good, though.  Nothing stand-out or stellar, but it did the trick.
author: daphne w.

description:
One word: Cockroach 

It left me wondering what was in the Orange Chicken. Hmm.
author: Chris B.

description:
Remember that recurring skid in Sesame Street with Groover as a restaurant waiter and a guest who would wonder all the time why he'd come back to the place time and again? That's me and Bamboo. I so want to like them - and have a good Chinese restaurant in walking distance, too, so I give them lots of grace. 

Last time it was a bit rough, though. I had my usual filling cup of Hot & Sour Soup and wanted to try out the Sesame Chicken. Alas, when I opened the box at home, I found Shanghai Chicken inside - "sauteed diced chicken white meat & pinenuts w/ smoke green leafs" according to the menu. If only. It looked as if somebody already ate it and decided to put it back in the to go box. It smelled really, really bad. It tasted good, though - but due to the smell I couldn't finish it. And I was hungry.

Maybe I should try the real Sesame Chicken but I couldn't convince myself to do it yet.
author: Roland A.

description:
I discovered Bamboo when I lived in the lower Nob Hill area a few years ago. It soon became a favorite. I don't necessarily consider this restaurant a typical Chinese restaurant, but rather, a healthy and vegetarian-friendly alternative. The food isn't the most delicious I've ever eaten, but because it's so healthy, I often feel awesome after eating here. 

Since I don't eat meat, I haven't tried their meat dishes, but my son loves getting their barbecued duck, and other meat-eaters I've brought here, loved it. I love the fact that they offer fluffy brown rice as an alternative to white rice and they serve free soup and salad at dinnertime. The soup is a simple veggie broth with assorted vegetables. Some people may find it bland, but I find it comforting and warming on a cold San Francisco night. The salad consists of shredded purple cabbage with a sesame dressing. Am I the only person who loves cabbage? It seems I'm the only one who chows on this salad. 

I often ask the staff to make me custom dishes. Since they serve fake chicken in one of their dishes, I ask them to replace real chicken in a dish such as Sesame Chicken with the fake. They've never, ever complained. 

The staff is a pleasure. When I lived in the neighborhood they knew my family, and they were extra nice to my son. The atmosphere is quite peaceful and lovely with its colorful decor, dim lights, and plants; feels kind of zen. Even though I live in a different neighborhood now, I often return to Polk Street to dine at Bamboo.
author: L. L.

description:
Okay -- so, like, this used to be my favorite place to order Chinese food at in the neighborhood i work at --- but it's sooooo NOT anymore!  Sure their food is tasty but it's because of all the soy sauce they put in their food.  But the more dishes you order the more they kinda taste the same.  It's as if they've made a vat of one particular sauce and use it for all their dishes.  

HOWEVER-- I would have to say that the General Chao's chicken is quite the delicious treat.  Deep fried goodness with  flavorful seasonings.  

Don't get me wrong. I'll still order from here because they can deliver my food in about about 15 minutes (it comes in handy when I get so busy at my desk that I forget to eat lunch and I look at my clock to realize it's already 3:30pm--yeah happens a lot).

So 1 star for the fast delivery.  2 stars for the general chao's chicken. Woohoo!
author: Anne M.

description:
The most delicious potstickers in the city. 

Oh and they never judge me for calling for delivery even though I only live 5 blocks away.
author: Melissa H.

description:
So far so good...was hungry for chinese and decided to get some takeout. Based on the bad delivery reviews...I decided to go for a walk and pick it up myself.

The service was very quick and the food was fairly affordable for evening takeout. The sesame chicken was delicious and nicely spiced. So I can't really complain.
